link.title: The Apology Gap: Same Words, Different Fears

entry.content:
What your brain is actually computing when an apology doesnâ€™t land

Someone says â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ and instead of feeling better, you feelâ€¦ off.

Not angrier.
Not more hurt.
Just unconvincedâ€”like a box was checked, but not your box.

Most people recognize this feeling immediately. Fewer can explain it.
And almost everyone has, at some point, been told: â€œThey apologizedâ€”what more do you want?â€

That question turns out to be doing a lot of hidden work.

When an apology feels empty, itâ€™s usually because it answered a different question than the one you were asking.

(A note on scope: this essay is about personal relationships, primarily in Western cultural contexts. Apologies work differently in professional, institutional, and cross-cultural settingsâ€”thatâ€™s a different essay, and probably a longer one.)

What Your Brain Is Actually Asking

On the surface, it sounds like people are judging sincerity. Did they mean it? Was it genuine?

But if you watch your own reactions carefully, thatâ€™s rarely what determines how an apology lands.

Whatâ€™s actually happening is closer to this:

Given this apology, what am I supposed to believe now?

Believe about whether they understand the harm. Whether this is likely to happen again. Whether the relationship feels stable or fragile.

In other words, apologies arenâ€™t just moral gestures (or attempts to get you to stop looking at them like that).

Theyâ€™re informational signalsâ€”probability estimates about future behavior. People use them, quietly and intuitively, to update expectations about what comes next.

This isnâ€™t cynicism.
Itâ€™s prediction.

Think of an apology like a weather forecast.

â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ doesnâ€™t mean â€œit will never rain again.â€

It means: â€œbased on current conditions, thereâ€™s a reasonable chance I understand what went wrong.â€

Some apologies say 40% chance of understanding, clearing by tomorrow. Others say I didnâ€™t see it before, but now I doâ€”expect different conditions ahead.

Neither is a guarantee.
But one gives you more to work with.

TL;DR

Youâ€™re not grading apologies on politeness. Youâ€™re using them to predict what happens next.

The Part We Rarely Say Out Loud: Apologies Do Different Jobs

One reason this gets messy is that people donâ€™t actually agree on what an apology is for.

There are at least two models in play.

The Signal Model

In this model, an apology exists to mark a boundary. It says: I acknowledge something went wrong. I recognize the norm. We can close this now.

This kind of apology is efficient. It keeps social systems running. It prevents every small rupture from turning into a postmortem.

It also quietly ends a lot of conversations.

And often, thatâ€™s exactly what should happen.

Not every rupture needs a postmortem. Not every misstep requires excavation. Signal apologies are the social immune systemâ€”they handle the routine infections so the body can function. Without them, every relationship would collapse under the weight of its own processing.

The problem isnâ€™t Signal apologies. Itâ€™s when theyâ€™re the only tool in the kit.

The Process Model

In this model, an apology is expected to reflect internal change. It says: I understand something I didnâ€™t before. My interpretation has updated. That update should show up later.

This model prioritizes recalibration over closure.

Both models are coherent.
Both are common.
Both use the same word: sorry.

This isâ€¦ inconvenient. (Or catastrophic, depending on your anxiety levels. Itâ€™s essentially a terms-of-service disagreement where neither party read the terms.)

To see why, consider what an apology is technically supposed to do. Research identifies four key components that effective apologies typically address [1]:

Component What It Says Signal Apology Process Apology
Acknowledge â€œSomething I did affected you negatively.â€ âœ“ âœ“
Accept Responsibility â€œI did it. Not the weather. Not your tone.â€ âœ“ âœ“
Express Remorse â€œI feel bad about that impact.â€ ~ âœ“
Commit to Change â€œFuture behavior should differ.â€ ~ âœ“

Signal apologies tend to hit (1) and (2)â€”enough to mark the transaction complete. (The relational equivalent of marking an email as â€˜readâ€™.) Process apologies are expected to deliver all four, with (3) and (4) doing the heavy lifting. Research shows that the depth of emotional expression and genuine commitment to change differentiates truly reparative apologies from merely transactional ones [2].

Think of it like legal settlements. They donâ€™t prove moral enlightenment; they stop the bleeding. Signal apologies work the same way. Thatâ€™s not a bugâ€”itâ€™s a coordination feature. But it optimizes for social stability, not relational depth.

TL;DR

People often give the apology they believe is appropriate, not the one the other person is evaluating.

A Simple Example That Gets Complicated Fast

Imagine this:

Jamie makes a joke at a group dinner. It lands badlyâ€”not maliciously, but it stings. Later, they say: â€œHey, sorry about earlier.â€

That response might feel sufficient.
Or dismissive.
Or oddly hollow.

Now add context.

Itâ€™s not the first time. Jamie apologizes quicklyâ€”always. They donâ€™t like revisiting things once theyâ€™ve been addressed. But theyâ€™re otherwise supportive, reliable, the person who shows up when it matters.

At this point, the apology stops being a single event. It becomes part of a pattern.

And patterns carry far more information than words.

One apology is weak evidence. Your brain knows this, even when you wish it didnâ€™t. What actually moves your inference is repeated behaviorâ€”apologies that expand over time, or ones that stay shallow no matter the stakes.

Now flip it.

Imagine youâ€™re on the other side of the table. You said something careless. You know it. You apologizeâ€”quickly, because thatâ€™s how you show you care. You donâ€™t want this to fester.

But instead of landing, your apology opens a door you didnâ€™t expect. Now there are questions. Follow-ups. A request to â€œtalk about what happened.â€ Youâ€™re being asked to narrate your internal state, reconstruct your intent, and demonstrate understandingâ€”on demand, in real time.

You already felt bad.
Now you feel interrogated.

This is the reverse Jamie problem. And itâ€™s just as real.

Some people experience process-level repair not as care, but as an emotional audit they can never quite pass. The goalpost isnâ€™t visible. The â€œrightâ€ answer keeps shifting. The conversation doesnâ€™t feel like connectionâ€”it feels like a test with no answer key.

That exhaustion isnâ€™t avoidance.
Itâ€™s its own kind of hurt.

Why Closeness Makes This Harder, Not Easier

Thereâ€™s a common assumption that closer relationships naturally default to deeper apologies.

Intuitively, it makes senseâ€”more investment, more care, more willingness to go further.

In practice, closeness mainly does one thing: it raises the cost of being wrong.

A shallow apology from a stranger is forgettable. The same apology from someone close feels diagnosticâ€”like itâ€™s telling you something you didnâ€™t want to know.

Thatâ€™s because intimacy doesnâ€™t increase certainty.
It increases stakes.
(Thanks, evolution.)

This is where many people misfire. They interpret a mismatch in apology depth as a lack of care, when itâ€™s often a mismatch in optimization strategy.

Some people optimize for minimizing conflict durationâ€”restoring equilibrium quickly, preventing escalation. Others optimize for shared understandingâ€”reduced future risk, internal alignment.

Same interaction.
Different goals.

(Nobody puts â€œoptimizes for conflict minimizationâ€ in their dating profile. It probably wouldnâ€™t help if they did.)

Hereâ€™s the part thatâ€™s easy to miss: some people genuinely believe conflict itself is the woundâ€”so ending it fast is the care. For them, a drawn-out process apology doesnâ€™t feel connective. It feels like reopening something that should be healing.

That doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re right. It also doesnâ€™t mean that their optimization function is brokenâ€”itâ€™s just pointing somewhere else.

(Yes, attachment theory is lurking in the background. Weâ€™ll get there. First, letâ€™s build the framework without assuming youâ€™ve already done three years of therapy.)

Back to Jamie.

Jamieâ€™s consistent, quick apologies might mean: I care and want this resolved so we can move forward.

Or they might mean: This pattern works well enoughâ€”why change it?

You canâ€™t tell from one instance.

But you can tell from twenty.

A rough heuristic: one data pointâ€”suspend judgment. Two aligned data pointsâ€”update gently. Three aligned data points across different contexts? Treat that as a stable parameter, not noise.

TL;DR

One apology is a data point. A pattern is a signal.

Where It Gets Complicated

The framework so far has been charitableâ€”perhaps too charitable. Reality includes at least four complications that donâ€™t fit cleanly into â€˜different preferences.â€™ Letâ€™s name them.

1. Strategy Exists

WARNING

Not all shallow apologies are preference-driven or model-mismatched. Some are strategic.

That doesnâ€™t mean malicious.

It means responsive to incentive structure of the interaction rather than reflective of actual understanding or care.

This aligns with research showing apologies function as costly signals that must be credible to restore trust [7].

If shallow apologies reliably reset the situationâ€”end the conversation, restore access, avoid consequencesâ€”then shallow apologies are efficient. Over time, repeated signal-only apologies arenâ€™t confusion.

Theyâ€™re data.

Jamieâ€™s quick apologies always seem to arrive right before youâ€™ve decided whether to bring it up. Coincidence? Maybe. But if a pattern consistently preempts the conversation you need to have, at some point youâ€™re not observing remorse. Youâ€™re observing a well-timed reset button.

Ignoring this leads to overly generous interpretations that donâ€™t match reality.

2. â€œCanâ€™tâ€ and â€œWonâ€™tâ€ Look the Same

Another place people get stuck: collapsing â€œthey canâ€™tâ€ and â€œthey wonâ€™t.â€

From the outside, these look the sameâ€”discomfort with follow-up, vague wording, pressure to move on.

But the implications are different.

Capacity limits suggest you might need to adjust expectations. Willingness limits suggest you might need to make a boundary decision.

Thereâ€™s also a third possibility worth naming: they can go deeper but believe they shouldnâ€™t. Some people avoid process-level apologies because claiming full understanding feels dishonest to them. Theyâ€™re not withholdingâ€”theyâ€™re being epistemically humble about the limits of knowing another personâ€™s experience.

This can produce apologies that sound dismissive (â€œIâ€™m sorry you felt that wayâ€) but arenâ€™t actually indifferent. The restraint is the point.

And hereâ€™s the part nobody wants to admit: process apologies are expensive.

Not in a â€œthis is hardâ€ wayâ€”in an actual resource-depletion way. They require emotional bandwidth, cognitive load, vulnerability, and time. Theyâ€™re the full cardiovascular workout of interpersonal repair.

Signal apologies are a brisk walk to the fridge.

Neither is wrong.

But if youâ€™re expecting someone to do the full workout for every minor friction, youâ€™re going to run out of relationship before you run out of conflicts.

This is where frequency quietly becomes the variable everyone ignores.

If you have two serious conflicts a year, process apologies are sustainable. If you have fifty small frictions, demanding process-level repair each time is a recipe for mutual exhaustion. At some point, the math doesnâ€™t workâ€”not because anyone stopped caring, but because humans have finite metabolic reserves for emotional deep-dives.

The failure mode isnâ€™t â€œthey wonâ€™t do the work.â€

Sometimes itâ€™s â€œthe work exceeds the available supply of work.â€

(This is also why some people seem to have infinite patience for repair in new relationships and none in long ones. The emotional account got overdrawn. Interest compounded. The bank is now sending letters.)

You donâ€™t have to diagnose which is which immediately. You do have to notice which one you keep assuming.

Thereâ€™s a shadow version of this worth naming: process apologies can be their own kind of avoidance.

Not always. But sometimes.

Insisting on deep processing after every friction can function as a control mechanismâ€”keeping the other person in a permanent state of emotional accountability. â€œWe need to talk about thisâ€ can be genuine repair. It can also be a way of never letting something be finished.

The person demanding depth isnâ€™t always seeking understanding. Sometimes theyâ€™re seeking reassurance that canâ€™t be permanently given. Sometimes the processing is the problemâ€”not because theyâ€™re wrong to want it, but because no amount of it will ever feel like enough.

If signal apologies can be strategic, process apologies can be compulsive.

Both failure modes exist. Most advice only names one.

Jamie, for what itâ€™s worth, probably falls somewhere in the middle of this. Most people do. The uncomfortable part isnâ€™t diagnosing which one Jamie isâ€”itâ€™s admitting you might not want to know.

3. Power Changes the Math

DANGER

All of this becomes more complicated when risks arenâ€™t equal [8]. Power imbalances fundamentally change what apologies are safe to demand and what communication patterns emerge.

Consider: an employee raising a concern with a manager. A partner whoâ€™s more emotionally invested than the other. A friend who needs the relationship more.

In unequal dynamics, signal apologies often function as containment toolsâ€”not maliciously, but structurally. The person with less power may not be able to safely push for clarity, even when they need it.

The framework still applies. But inference happens under unequal risk, and â€œjust communicate betterâ€ advice tends to collapse here. (â€œJust communicate betterâ€ is the â€œhave you tried turning it off and on againâ€ of relationship advice. Technically correct. Practically useless when the power button is on someone elseâ€™s desk.)

Jamie, it turns out, sets the emotional pace in most of your interactions. You adjust your timing to theirs. You pre-edit your concerns to fit their tolerance window. Youâ€™ve gotten so good at translating yourself into Jamie-compatible formats that you sometimes forget what the original file sounded like.

That doesnâ€™t mean they donâ€™t care. It does mean the cost of pressing for more falls disproportionately on you.

4. The Apology That Landed in the Wrong Language

Thereâ€™s a failure mode nobody talks about because it doesnâ€™t have a clean villain.

Someone does the work. They sit with the discomfort, replay the interaction, figure out what went wrongâ€”not because you demanded it, but because it bothered them. They come back with something real. Maybe itâ€™s not eloquent. Maybe it arrives at an odd time, or in a format you didnâ€™t expect. Maybe it sounds like â€œI kept thinking about what happened at dinner and I donâ€™t think I was being fair to youâ€ instead of the five-paragraph emotional essay your nervous system was waiting for.

And it doesnâ€™t land.

Not because it was shallow. Because your pattern-detection was already locked in. Youâ€™d seen enough formulaic apologies from enough people that your filter was running on high sensitivityâ€”catching everything that looked even slightly rehearsed, including this. The apology got sorted into the â€œperformed remorseâ€ bin before you finished hearing it.

(Your sincerity filter doesnâ€™t publish its false-positive rate. It doesnâ€™t think it has one.)

The damage is quiet but specific. The person who did the internal work walks away thinking that wasnâ€™t enough either, so why bother? The person who dismissed it may never know what they missed. And the next time that person considers going deeper, theyâ€™ll remember that it didnâ€™t matter when they did.

(Jamie, on occasion, might actually be this person. Thatâ€™s the version of the story Iâ€™m least comfortable tellingâ€”not because itâ€™s unlikely, but because it means some of my careful inference was just well-dressed suspicion.)

Receivers can be miscalibrated too. If youâ€™ve been hurt enough times by shallow apologies, your threshold for â€œgenuineâ€ can drift so high that almost nothing clears it. At that point, youâ€™re not protecting yourself anymore. Youâ€™re rejecting things you actually needed and calling it discernment.

And thatâ€™s not the same as disregard.

The Reframe That Actually Helps

Hereâ€™s the shift that makes this framework practical instead of just interesting:

An apology isnâ€™t a verdict. Itâ€™s a data point.

It doesnâ€™t answer: Do they care?

It updates: How likely is it that they understand in the way that matters here?

And hereâ€™s the quieter update that often hurts more:

How likely is it that weâ€™re even playing the same game?

Your discomfort after a hollow apology often isnâ€™t about the apology itself.

Itâ€™s your estimate of shared relational assumptions drifting downward.

Thatâ€™s a different kind of loss.

Once you see that, a few things shift:

  • Discomfort after an apology often signals insufficient information, not ingratitude
  • The question changes from â€œDid they mean it?â€ to â€œWhat does the pattern suggest?â€
  • Your unease might be tracking something realâ€”a growing sense that youâ€™re not playing the same game

This doesnâ€™t mean turning every apology into an audit. Interpretation itself has a cost. Thereâ€™s a failure mode where you never let anything settle, treating every word as evidence to be weighed. Thatâ€™s not insightâ€”itâ€™s anxiety with spreadsheets.

(I have personally filed these spreadsheets. They are not helpful.)

The goal isnâ€™t maximum analysis.

Itâ€™s accurate inference, over time.

The Part Where Psychology Gets Uncomfortably Relevant

If the reframe above clicked, this next part will explain why itâ€™s so hard to actually apply.

If youâ€™ve been nodding along thinking â€œthis explains that one person,â€ congratulations: youâ€™ve arrived at the attachment theory portion of our program.

(Donâ€™t worry. Weâ€™re not turning this into astrology. Unless youâ€™re a Gemini. Just kidding. Brief detour, then back to earth.)

People donâ€™t enter conflicts neutrally. They bring priorsâ€”not just about this argument, but about what conflict means. Attachment theory [3] tells us that early relationship experiences create lasting (but not permanent) patterns in how we approach closeness, conflict, and repair [4], [5].

These patterns are the background operating system that processes apologies before the words even land. So the same apologyâ€”same words, same tone, same timingâ€”can feel like abandonment to one person (â€œThey didnâ€™t go deep enough; do they even care?â€) and like a reasonable close to another (â€œI acknowledged it; why are we still here?â€).

Neither is imagining things. Theyâ€™re just running different firmware.

(Importantly: firmware can be updated. Earned secure attachment is well-documented [5]â€”these patterns are stubborn defaults, not life sentences. But the update cycle is measured in years and good therapy, not in one conversation.)

This is annoying, because it means the question â€œWas that apology good enough?â€ doesnâ€™t have a context-free answer. It depends on what each personâ€™s nervous system is scanning for.

Jamieâ€™s quick apologies might genuinely feel complete to Jamieâ€”not because Jamie doesnâ€™t care, but because Jamieâ€™s system registers â€œconflict acknowledged, threat neutralized, return to baseline.â€ Meanwhile, your system is still running: â€œBut did they understand? Is it safe now?â€

Two different threat models.
Same room.

And hereâ€™s what gets lost in most writing about this (including, until this paragraph, this one): Jamieâ€™s experience of that mismatch isnâ€™t neutral either.

If your system reads their quick apology as abandonment, their system may read your need for processing as an escalation threat. You feel uncared for. They feel unsafe. Youâ€™re both scanning for dangerâ€”just in opposite directions.

The person who closes quickly isnâ€™t always fleeing.
Sometimes theyâ€™re protectingâ€”themselves, the relationship, the fragile peace theyâ€™ve worked to build.

That protection can look like indifference from the outside.
From the inside, it often feels like survival.

This doesnâ€™t make mismatches less painful. It makes them more symmetrical than they appear.

The practical upshot: if you keep having the same fight about apologies, you might not be disagreeing about words. You might be disagreeing about what repair is.

Thatâ€™s harder to fix.
Also more useful to know.

Closure for one person can be erasure for another. The trick is learning which one youâ€™re being offeredâ€”and deciding whether itâ€™s enough.

The Error Tradeoff

All of thisâ€”the complications, the firmware, the symmetryâ€”converges on a tradeoff most people never name: every time you interpret an apology, youâ€™re implicitly choosing which mistake youâ€™re willing to risk.

Believing Jamieâ€™s quick apology means understandingâ€”and maybe youâ€™re trusting a well-practiced reset button. Thatâ€™s a false positive. The cost is resentment: staying in a pattern that never actually changes, because you kept giving credit for words that werenâ€™t backed by anything.

Dismiss Jamieâ€™s quick apology as shallowâ€”and maybe youâ€™re rejecting the best Jamie knew how to offer. Thatâ€™s a false negative. The cost is the apology that landed in the wrong language: real care, filtered out by a system tuned too aggressively against being fooled, causing loneliness.

Error Type The Jamie Version The Regret
False Positive Believing Jamieâ€™s quick apologies mean understandingâ€”when theyâ€™re just a well-practiced reset button Resentment (stayed too long)
False Negative Dismissing Jamieâ€™s quick apologies as shallowâ€”when they were the best Jamie knew how to offer Loneliness (left too early)

Neither mistake is irrational. They optimize for different regrets [10].

Hereâ€™s what I eventually realized: Iâ€™d been running almost entirely on false-positive protection.

Every Jamie interaction got filtered through â€œbut do they really get it?â€

Meanwhile, Jamie might have been running the opposite filter: â€œI said I was sorry; why isnâ€™t that landing?â€

We were both protecting ourselvesâ€”just in opposite directions.

Same dinners. Same apologies. Different fears.

Most people donâ€™t realize theyâ€™ve chosen a side. They think theyâ€™re just reading the situation accurately.

But that invisible choice shapes everything downstream: how much evidence you demand, how charitably you interpret silence, whether you lean in or pull back.

The question worth asking isnâ€™t â€œWhoâ€™s right about the apology?â€

Itâ€™s: Which mistake can I live with, for this particular Jamie?

That doesnâ€™t give you an answer.

But it gives you a better questionâ€”one thatâ€™s actually about your situation, not about apologies in the abstract.

TL;DR

Youâ€™re not choosing between trust and boundaries. Youâ€™re choosing which mistake you can live with.

For the probability nerds: the part where I pretend relationships are tractable

The Core Question

When someone apologizes, youâ€™re implicitly asking: â€œGiven what I just observed, how likely is it that they actually understand?â€

Letâ€™s call this \(P(U \mid A)\)â€”the probability of genuine Understanding given the Apology you observed.

Building the Model

Step 1: The Basic Update

Bayesâ€™ theorem tells us how to update beliefs given new evidence:

\[P(U \mid A) = \frac{P(A \mid U) \cdot P(U)}{P(A)}\]

In plain English:

  • \(P(U)\) = Your prior belief they understand (before this apology)
  • \(P(A \mid U)\) = How likely is this apology if they truly understand?
  • \(P(A \mid \neg U)\) = How likely is this apology if they donâ€™t understand?
  • \(P(A)\) = How likely is this apology in general?

Step 2: Why Words Alone Are Weak Evidence

The key insight is the likelihood ratio:

\[\text{LR} = \frac{P(A \mid U)}{P(A \mid \neg U)}\]

If someone can easily say â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ whether or not they understand, then \(P(A \mid U) \approx P(A \mid \neg U)\), and \(\text{LR} \approx 1\).

A likelihood ratio of 1 means: this evidence doesnâ€™t move your beliefs at all.

How LR actually updates your belief:

Bayesâ€™ theorem has a simpler form that makes this concrete. Instead of probabilities, think in odds:

\[\underbrace{\frac{P(U \mid A)}{P(\neg U \mid A)}}_{\text{Posterior odds}} = \underbrace{\frac{P(U)}{P(\neg U)}}_{\text{Prior odds}} \times \underbrace{\text{LR}}_{\text{Evidence strength}}\]

In plain English: your updated belief = your old belief Ã— the strength of the evidence.

If the LR is 1, you multiply by 1 â€” nothing changes. If itâ€™s 5, your odds quintuple. If itâ€™s 0.5, they halve. Thatâ€™s it. Thatâ€™s the whole machine.

(To convert back to probability: \(P = \frac{\text{odds}}{1 + \text{odds}}\). So odds of 3:1 â†’ probability of 75%.)

Evidence Type Likelihood Ratio Belief Update
Formulaic â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ ~1.0 Almost none
Accurate paraphrase of harm ~3-5 Moderate
Behavior change weeks later ~10+ Strong
Unprompted follow-up ~5-10 Strong

(These numbers are vibes-calibrated, not empirically measured. If youâ€™re looking for a peer-reviewed likelihood ratio table for apology sincerity, I regret to inform you that academia has let us down.)

A Worked Example: The Jamie Update

Letâ€™s say your prior on Jamie is generous: 60% belief they understand (\(P(U) = 0.6\)). Jamieâ€™s generally thoughtful, after all.

In odds: \(\frac{0.6}{0.4} = 1.5\) (you believe understanding is 1.5Ã— more likely than not).

Jamie gives a formulaic sorry after the dinner incident. \(\text{LR} \approx 1.0\). Updated odds: \(1.5 \times 1.0 = 1.5\). Posterior: still 60%. The apology was perfectly nice and perfectly uninformative.

A month later, similar friction, same formulaic sorry. \(\text{LR} \approx 0.8\) this timeâ€”slight evidence against understanding, because now itâ€™s a pattern. Updated odds: \(1.5 \times 0.8 = 1.2\). Posterior: \(\frac{1.2}{2.2} \approx 55\%\).

Then, three weeks after that, Jamie does something unprompted. They bring up the dinner thingâ€”not because you asked, but because theyâ€™d been thinking about it. \(\text{LR} \approx 8\). Updated odds: \(1.2 \times 8 = 9.6\). Posterior: \(\frac{9.6}{10.6} \approx 91\%\).

Thatâ€™s why the unprompted follow-up three weeks later meant more than both apologies combined. Your brain knew this. Now you know why your brain knew this.

Adding Complexity: The Full Model

The article discussed several factors. Letâ€™s formalize them.

Factor 1: Apology Type

Let \(T \in \{\text{Signal}, \text{Process}\}\) represent the apology type. We actually care about:

\[P(U \mid A, T) = \frac{P(A \mid U, T) \cdot P(U \mid T)}{P(A \mid T)}\]

Process apologies are harder to fake, so:

  • \[P(A_{\text{deep}} \mid U, T_{\text{Process}}) \gg P(A_{\text{deep}} \mid \neg U, T_{\text{Process}})\]

This is why process apologies carry more informationâ€”the likelihood ratio is much higher.

Factor 2: Patterns Over Time

With \(n\) observations \(A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n\):

\[P(U \mid A_1, \ldots, A_n) \propto P(U) \cdot \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{P(A_i \mid U)}{P(A_i \mid \neg U)}\]

(Technically these observations arenâ€™t independentâ€”Jamieâ€™s apologies are correlated because Jamie is, stubbornly, the same person each time. A proper model would account for this autocorrelation. I will not be building a proper model. If you are building one, please see a therapist.)

Even with the simplification, the intuition holds: if each shallow apology has \(\text{LR} = 0.8\) (slight evidence against understanding), then after 10 observations:

\[\text{Combined LR} = 0.8^{10} \approx 0.11\]

Your belief in genuine understanding drops by ~90%. Patterns compound.

Factor 3: The Strategy Discount

When someone has incentives to apologize strategically, we need:

\[P(A \mid \neg U, \text{Strategic}) > P(A \mid \neg U, \text{Non-strategic})\]

Strategic apologizers are more likely to produce apology \(A\) even without understandingâ€”so the same words become weaker evidence. This is why context matters: an apology that arrives conveniently after youâ€™ve threatened consequences is less informative than an unprompted one.

(Think of it like online reviews. A five-star review from someone who got a discount is weaker evidence than one from someone who paid full price. Same stars. Different priors on their motivation.)

Factor 4: Power Dynamics

Define \(\text{Power}_{\text{them}} > \text{Power}_{\text{you}}\). In this case:

\[P(\text{You push for clarity} \mid \text{Power imbalance}) \ll P(\text{You push for clarity} \mid \text{Equal power})\]

This doesnâ€™t change what apologies meanâ€”it changes what apologies you get to observe. Your data is censored by power, which biases your estimates. You think youâ€™re working with the full dataset. Youâ€™re actually working with the survivorship-biased highlight reel.

(Statisticians call this selection bias. Therapists call this â€œthe thing youâ€™ve been avoiding.â€ Same phenomenon, different billing rates.)

Factor 5: Receiver Miscalibration (The Drifting Threshold)

This is the factor the model doesnâ€™t naturally account for, because itâ€™s about the observer, not the evidence.

Factors 1â€“4 assume your evaluation function is stableâ€”that youâ€™re weighing each apology against a fixed standard. But what if the standard itself has shifted?

Define \(\tau_t\) as your trust threshold at time \(t\). Model it as a function of accumulated negative experiences, bounded between 0 and 1:

\[\tau_t = 1 - (1 - \tau_0) \cdot \exp\left(-\alpha \sum_{i=1}^{N} w_i\right)\]

where:

  • \(\tau_0\) is your baseline threshold (set by temperament, attachment history, and whether your last three relationships ended via text message)
  • \(\alpha > 0\) is your sensitivity to negative experiences
  • \(w_i > 0\) weights each negative experience by severity and recency

This is a saturating function: it approaches 1 asymptotically but never reaches it. In practice, this means your threshold can get very highâ€”but never quite hits â€œnothing will ever be enough,â€ which is both mathematically convenient and psychologically generous.

The critical problem: \(w_i\) doesnâ€™t distinguish between this personâ€™s track record and everyone elseâ€™s. Bad experiences with past Jamies leak into your prior for the current one. Your threshold for trusting Jamie is partly a function of what happened with someone Jamie has never met.

(Your exâ€™s apologies are still in the training data. You didnâ€™t consent to this. Neither did Jamie.)

Worse, this creates a positive feedback loopâ€”what control theorists would recognize as a system with no negative feedback to stabilize it:

  1. High \(\tau_t\) â†’ reject more apologies (including genuine ones)
  2. Rejected genuine apologies â†’ the other person reduces effort (rational response to perceived futility)
